Ground clearance is about 3/8"

Competing this weekend at Central Missouri in Sedalia and at the Iowa Regional in a couple of weeks.

john3928:

Slammed Swerve

I’m just confused what this is, it just looks like a ground clearance drop.

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked: I believe it’s a reference to car culture. People call their cars slammed because of the way the wheels are “slammed” into wheel wells, making their car super low to the ground.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: No algae are going to get sucked under that thing! [Citation needed]
It is just a clearance drop, and that seems to be very common this year as teams try to avoid getting algae caught under them.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman

posts.cooked: No motors inside of wheels? Unsubscribe

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Lil_Lavery:

No motors inside of wheels?

For S&G I was Crayon CAD’ing a Neo 550 sized remix to see just how small it could be.  I should finish that.

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked:
Does a clearance drop really protect against algae?

I was thinking a bumper raise could help with ensuring your swerve wheels have traction when the robot is tilted, allowing you to get off the algae easier. But maybe the high clearance could result in more instances of getting stuck on algae in the first place…

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
John_Bottenberg:

Does a clearance drop really protect against algae?

My conjecture is having your CG below the height in which you contact the algae is helpful.  So low CG, plus tall(ish) bumpers.   From watching other teams, I would say choosing slick bumper fabric is a big win as well.
